Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: The process always starts with 'Receive order.' After that, the next step is to 'Check inventory' to see if the items requested are available.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Depending on the inventory check, the process can take two paths: If inventory is sufficient, the sequence is Receive -> Check -> Authorize -> Package -> Ship -> Close. If insufficient, the sequence is Receive -> Check -> Cancel -> Close.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: From this, I can infer the key constraints: Authorize payment should only happen after Check inventory. Package items should occur after Authorize and before Ship. Ship should never happen after Cancel. Close should always be the final activity.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Case 1 matches the described process perfectly: Receive -> Check -> Authorize -> Package -> Ship -> Close. No violations.

Name: Validation - NE
Text: Case 2 violates the normative process because Package items occurs before Authorize payment, which is a reversal of the expected sequence.

Name: Validation - NE
Text: Case 3 violates the process in two ways: Authorize payment occurs before Cancel order, even though inventory appears insufficient. Additionally, Ship order occurs after Cancel order, which is clearly incorrect.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Case 4 is correct for the insufficient inventory scenario: Receive -> Check -> Cancel -> Close. No violations.

Name: Validation - NE
Text: Case 5 violates the process because Package items is skipped entirely. Ship occurs directly after Authorize payment, violating the constraint that Package must precede Ship.
